column1: Aldosterone plays a crucial role in sodium and potassium balance
The hormone is secreted by the adrenal glands
Aldosterone increases the reabsorption of sodium in the kidneys
This action, in turn, leads to the excretion of potassium
The regulation of aldosterone is primarily by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
When blood pressure is low or sodium levels are low, the body releases renin
Renin activates angiotensin, which then stimulates the adrenal glands to produce aldosterone
Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption, which helps to raise blood pressure and maintain fluid balance
The balance between aldosterone's effects on sodium and potassium is essential for homeostasis
Any disruption in aldosterone regulation can lead to electrolyte imbalances
Therefore, aldosterone is vital for maintaining the correct levels of sodium and potassium in the body
Understanding its role helps in comprehending how the body manages fluid and electrolyte balance
